thread.title: Corruption Currents: U.K. Refuses Raids in Money-Laundering Probe

author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: U.K. Refuses Raids in Money-Laundering Probe
text:
0 COMMENTS People walk by a shop with the logo of the mobile network operator Lycamobile in Paris on Aug. 29, 2015. Photo: THOMAS SAMSON/AFP/Getty Images 
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery: 
Liberia’s president ordered a probe into a 2013 oil deal with ExxxonMobil Corp. Exxon didn’t immediately comment; it previously said the deal complied with all antigraft laws. (Bloomberg)
Mexico banned government agencies from doing business with Odebrecht for 30 months and fined the company $60 million. (Reuters)
Swiss banks are hiring top lawyers as authorities investigate their role in Brazil’s Carwash scandal. Authorities are getting tougher on cross-border crime; activists want more . (Bloomberg, Reuters, SwissInfo)
Louis Berger scored a contract in India while under investigation. The company said it’s cooperating with authorities. (Wire, Quint)
South Korea’s government unveiled a five-year antibribery plan. (Yonhap)
Local cases: A former New Jersey police officer received prison in a police corruption scandal. A Long Island corruption trial continues . A juror in the U.K. who took a bribe was jailed . (NJ, Newsday, BBC)
Cybercrime: 
A data firm leaked 48 million profiles it scraped from social networks. (ZDNet)
The U.S. must act immediately to protect itself from Chinese cybertheft, said a Congressional watchdog. (SCMP)
Fraud: 
German police raided Porsche executives as part of an emissions-cheating scandal. The company confirmed the raids. (Local)
Money Laundering: 
U.K. lawmakers want to know why the government refused to help the French with a probe of a company suspected of money laundering and tax fraud. Reports said the U.K. tax authorities cited donations to the Tories as the reason. (BuzzFeed, BuzzFeed, Times)
Spanish authorities charged CaixaBank with laundering Chinese money. The bank denied the accusations. (AFP, Reuters)
Paul Manafort served as a back channel between the U.S. and Russia, prosecutors alleged in his money-laundering case. Mr. Manafort pleaded not guilty, is fighting back and wants access to his money. (Bloomberg, Politico, TPM, ABC, BuzzFeed)
Lawyers for Latvia’s ABLV Bank asked the U.S. to drop allegations of institutionalized money laundering. (LSM, AP)
The European parliament tightened rules on money laundering and terrorism finance. Latvia is pursuing more leads . (Expatica, GE, release, Bloomberg)
Citigroup seeks experts in cryptocurrency to beef up its anti-money laundering compliance staff. (BI)
A former bank executive was convicted of money laundering and tax evasion. The finance minister said executives committing misconduct will face prison. (SMH, Reuters)
Montenegro’s opposition leader faces money-laundering allegations; he denies them. (BI)
Liberia began a national risk assessment. (FPA)
Sanctions: 
European lawmakers urged Washington not to walk away from the Iran deal. (AFP, Reuters)
Why isn’t a former German chancellor on a Russia sanctions list ? (NPR)
Belgium exported sarin precursor to Syria, potentially violating sanctions. (Bellingcat, JP)
Terrorism Finance: 
A man accused of raising money for Hamas said he was actually at a meeting organized by a nonprofit. (TOI)
Transparency: 
Scottish companies failed to take a single action in a decade against a company for failing to comply with transparency rules. (HS)
New Zealand is setting up a database of beneficial owners. (Stuff, RadioNZ)
General Anti-Corruption: 
Investigators are piling on to probe allegations concerning the top U.S. environmental protection official. He denies wrongdoing. Accusations of self-dealing are coming for other administration officials. (Bloomberg, ABC, Quartz, Reuters, Bloomberg, DB)
Vietnam widened its anticorruption crackdown . (Reuters, AFP)
Venezuelan lawmakers, rendered essentially powerless, authorized exiled judges to begin a corruption probe of the president. (AP)
South African antigraft officials launched a probe into two ruling party politicians over corruption linked to a dairy farm. The story didn’t contain responses. (NYT)
Legal wrangling over files seized in a raid of U.S. President Donald Trump’s lawyer, Michael Cohen, continues. Allies of the president are concerned he’ll flip . (Reuters, Politico, Politico, VF)
Ukraine said it needs more anticorruption reforms to receive aid from the IMF. (Xinhua)
Match-fixing remains a problem in Hong Kong soccer. (SCMP)
